title: If F(x)=3x^2 + 1, G(x) = 2x - 3, what is F(G(x))? - Quora

response.answer_text: Good question. This problem is part of a series of function composition and decomposition. Given: F(G(x)) or f o g, where F(x) = 3x^2 + 1 and G(x) = 2x - 3. So, to start, you can go right in to the solving but for my explanation, I will first substitute G(x) with 2x - 3. Therefore, I get:F(G(x)) = F(2x-3)Since this is F(G(x)) and what we have is F(2x - 3) we can (and must!) plug-in 2x-3 for x, no matter how strange this might seem. We acquire the following:F(2x-3) = 3( 2x - 3)^2 + 1From here, we can simplify or leave the answer as is.Our final answer is therefore: 3( 2x - 3)^2 + 1

Given: If F(x)=3x^2 + 1, G(x) = 2x - 3, what is F(G(x))? Since F is the outer function, I’ll write F(x) where (____) is substituted in for x: F(____) = 3 (_____)^2 + 1 substitute G(x) in each space, so each space is filled with (2x-3) F( G(x) ) = 3 ( 2x -3 )^2 + 1F( G(x) ) = 3 ( 2x -3 ) ( 2x -3 ) + 1F( G(x) ) = 3 ( 4x^2 -12x + 9 ) + 1F( G(x) ) = 12x^2 -36x + 27 + 1F( G(x) ) = 12x^2 -36x + 28factor out the common 4F( G(x) ) = 4 ( 3x^2 -9x + 7 )
